Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of former Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos, has faced multiple asset freezes and sanctions across various jurisdictions due to allegations of embezzlement and money laundering during her tenure as chairwoman of Sonangol, Angola's state oil company.

**Angola:**

- In December 2022, Angola's Supreme Court ordered the preventive seizure of assets worth approximately $1 billion held by dos Santos. This decision was based on evidence of alleged embezzlement and money laundering. The seizure included her holdings in Angolan company Embalvidro, as well as 100% of shares in Cape Verde's telecom company Unitel T+ and Unitel STP in São Tomé and Príncipe. ([euronews.com](https://www.euronews.com/2022/12/28/angola-dossantos?utm_source=openai))

**Portugal:**

- In February 2020, following a request from Angolan authorities, Portugal froze dos Santos's bank accounts. This action was part of a broader effort to recover over $2 billion in stolen assets. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/feb/11/portugal-freezes-bank-accounts-of-isabel-dos-santos-after-angolan-request?utm_source=openai))

- In December 2023, a British court granted a worldwide freezing order on dos Santos's assets, valued at £580 million (approximately €670 million). This order was issued in connection with embezzlement charges brought forward by Unitel, an Angolan telecom company, stemming from business dealings involving dos Santos. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/dec/21/isabel-dos-santos-has-580m-of-assets-frozen-by-uk-high-court?utm_source=openai))

**United Kingdom:**

- In November 2024, the UK imposed sanctions against dos Santos, resulting in the freezing of her assets in the UK. ([rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com](https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0181R_1-2024-12-20.pdf?utm_source=openai))

**United States:**

- In December 2021, the U.S. State Department barred dos Santos and her immediate family from entering the United States, citing "significant corruption by misappropriating public funds for her personal benefit." ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabel_dos_Santos?utm_source=openai))

**European Union:**

- As of December 2025, there is no publicly available information indicating that the European Union has imposed sanctions or asset freezes on Isabel dos Santos.

Isabel dos Santos, daughter of former Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos, was once Africa's wealthiest woman, with a net worth estimated at $2 billion in 2025. ([nyongesasande.com](https://www.nyongesasande.com/top-10-richest-women-in-africa-in-2025-power-wealth-and-influence/?utm_source=openai)) She amassed her fortune through strategic investments in sectors such as telecommunications, banking, and energy. Notably, she held significant stakes in Unitel, Angola's largest telecom company, Banco BIC, and Portuguese oil giant Galp Energia. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabel_dos_Santos?utm_source=openai))

In 2016, Isabel dos Santos was appointed chairwoman of Sonangol, Angola's state oil firm, by her father. However, in November 2017, she was dismissed from this position. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonangol_Group?utm_source=openai)) Following her removal, she approved payments totaling $58 million from Sonangol to a Dubai-based company, Ironsea, co-owned by her and her associate Mário Leite da Silva. These transactions have been scrutinized, with allegations of misappropriation of funds. ([time.com](https://time.com/5769630/isabel-dos-santos-africa-allegations/?utm_source=openai))

In January 2024, Isabel dos Santos faced 11 criminal charges related to her tenure at Sonangol, including embezzlement, money laundering, and abuse of power. The Angolan government alleges that she misappropriated over $208 million during her time at the company. ([giranoticias.com](https://www.giranoticias.com/politica/2024/01/17800-isabel-dos-santos-acusada-de-11-crimes-no-processo-sonangol.html?utm_source=openai)) In November 2024, the British government imposed a travel ban and asset freeze on her under its global anti-corruption sanctions regime, accusing her of misappropriating more than £50 million from Sonangol and over £300 million from Unitel. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/britain-imposes-asset-freeze-travel-ban-angolas-isabel-dos-santos-2024-11-21/?utm_source=openai))

Despite these legal challenges and asset freezes, Isabel dos Santos continues to be a significant figure in African business, with her investments spanning multiple countries and industries.

The investigation was based on a leak of over 715,000 documents, including emails, contracts, organizational charts, meeting videos, loan agreements, and more. ([icij.org](https://www.icij.org/investigations/luanda-leaks/read-the-luanda-leaks-documents/?utm_source=openai))

**Key Findings:**

- **Asset Diversion:** The documents revealed that Isabel dos Santos, during her tenure as head of Angola's state oil company Sonangol, approved a $58 million transfer to a Dubai-based consultancy firm owned by a close friend just days before her dismissal. ([icij.org](https://www.icij.org/investigations/luanda-leaks/after-luanda-leaks-a-billionaires-empire-falls-but-her-enablers-carry-on/?utm_source=openai))

- **Offshore Holdings:** Dos Santos and her husband, Sindika Dokolo, established over 400 companies across 41 jurisdictions, including tax havens like Malta, Mauritius, and Hong Kong. These entities were linked to public contracts, consulting services, and loans in Angola. ([dw.com](https://www.dw.com/en/luanda-leaks-point-to-international-complicity-as-isabel-dos-santos-faces-scrutiny/a-52071069?utm_source=openai))

- **International Complicity:** The investigation highlighted the role of Western financial firms, lawyers, accountants, and government officials in facilitating these activities, raising concerns about the effectiveness of international regulatory systems in preventing such practices. ([dw.com](https://www.dw.com/en/luanda-leaks-point-to-international-complicity-as-isabel-dos-santos-faces-scrutiny/a-52071069?utm_source=openai))

**Reactions and Consequences:**

- **Legal Actions:** Following the revelations, Angolan authorities froze dos Santos' assets and charged her and her husband with embezzlement and money laundering. ([icij.org](https://www.icij.org/investigations/luanda-leaks/after-luanda-leaks-a-billionaires-empire-falls-but-her-enablers-carry-on/?utm_source=openai))

- **International Sanctions:** In November 2024, the UK imposed a travel ban and asset freeze on dos Santos under its global anti-corruption sanctions regime, citing misappropriation of funds during her leadership at Sonangol and Unitel. Isabel dos Santos, daughter of former Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos, has held significant ownership stakes in several major companies in Angola, including Unitel, Banco BIC, and ZAP Media.

**Unitel**

Isabel dos Santos owned a 25% stake in Unitel, Angola's largest mobile telecommunications company, through her company Vidatel Limited. In December 2019, the Angolan Supreme Court ordered the seizure of Unitel shares held by Vidatel, effectively removing her control over the company. ([africa-press.net](https://www.africa-press.net/angola/all-news/court-orders-seizure-of-isabel-dos-santos-assets?utm_source=openai))

**Banco BIC**

In 2014, dos Santos increased her stake in Banco BIC, Angola's largest bank, to 42.5% by acquiring an additional 17.5% from Portuguese billionaire Américo Amorim. ([forbes.com](https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2014/10/01/africas-richest-woman-acquires-17-5-additional-stake-in-angolan-bank/?utm_source=openai)) In 2017, the Angolan government froze assets belonging to dos Santos, including her shares in Banco BIC, as part of a broader investigation into alleged corruption. ([forbes.com](https://www.forbes.com/sites/kerryadolan/2020/01/03/angolan-billionaires-assets-frozen-by-countrys-court-worth-hundreds-of-millions-of-dollars/?utm_source=openai))

**ZAP Media**

Dos Santos held a 70% stake in ZAP Media, a leading cable and satellite television service in Angola, through her company Finstar – Sociedade de Investimentos e Participações. In 2017, the Angolan government seized assets belonging to dos Santos, including her shares in ZAP Media, as part of an investigation into alleged corruption. ([angola24horas.com](https://www.angola24horas.com/politica/item/15582-tribunal-angolano-arresta-bens-de-isabel-dos-santos-no-bfa-unitel-e-zap?utm_source=openai))

**Current Status**

As of December 2025, dos Santos has faced legal actions resulting in the seizure of her assets in Angola, including her stakes in Unitel, Banco BIC, and ZAP Media. In November 2024, the UK government imposed a travel ban and asset freeze on dos Santos under its global anti-corruption sanctions regime, citing misappropriation of funds during her tenure at Sonangol and Unitel. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/britain-imposes-asset-freeze-travel-ban-angolas-isabel-dos-santos-2024-11-21/?utm_source=openai))

Die Polizei von Dubai erklärte, dass nach einer Untersuchung kein kriminelles Fehlverhalten vermutet wurde. ([thenationalnews.com](https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/sindika-dokola-drowned-while-free-diving-in-dubai-say-police-1.1103286?utm_source=openai)) Dokolo war ein kongolesischer Geschäftsmann und Kunstsammler, der für seine Sammlung zeitgenössischer afrikanischer Kunst bekannt war. Er war seit 2002 mit Isabel dos Santos verheiratet, der Tochter des ehemaligen angolanischen Präsidenten José Eduardo dos Santos. Zu der Zeit seiner Todesfälle waren sowohl er als auch seine Frau in Korruptionsuntersuchungen verwickelt, wobei ihre Vermögenswerte in mehreren Ländern eingefroren wurden. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sindika_Dokolo?utm_source=openai)) Trotz der laufenden Ermittlungen und der damit verbundenen Kontroverse wurde der Tod von Dokolo von den Behörden als tragischer Unfall eingestuft.

output.search_result: Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of former Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos, has faced multiple legal challenges concerning her tenure at Sonangol, Angola's state oil company, between 2016 and 2017. In November 2025, the Angolan Supreme Court dismissed three of the eleven charges against her, including criminal association, abuse of power, and simple tax fraud. The court also exonerated the consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) of the charges it faced, citing that, at the time of the alleged offenses, the law did not hold legal entities criminally liable. ([aman-alliance.org](https://www.aman-alliance.org/Home/ContentDetail/97429?utm_source=openai)) Despite these dismissals, dos Santos still faces charges of embezzlement, aggravated fraud, breach of trust, economic participation in business, influence peddling, two counts of money laundering, and aggravated tax fraud. The Public Prosecutor's Office alleges that her actions resulted in losses exceeding $208 million to the Angolan state, citing improper salary payments, loss-making transactions, tax violations, and payments to companies linked to her interests. ([billionaires.africa](https://www.billionaires.africa/2025/11/22/isabel-dos-santos-africa-first-female-billionaire-cleared-charges/?utm_source=openai)) Regarding the trial's timeline, the contradictory instruction phase, an optional part of the criminal process aimed at presenting evidence to challenge the accusations, was initially scheduled for May 22, 2025. However, it was postponed to a later date, with no specific rescheduled date provided. ([aman-alliance.org](https://aman-alliance.org/Home/ContentDetail/90334?utm_source=openai)) As of December 2025, the trial has not yet commenced, and no final verdict has been reached. Dos Santos has consistently denied the allegations, claiming they are part of a politically motivated campaign. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/angolas-isabel-dos-santos-loses-appeal-against-freezing-order-over-assets-2024-09-30/?utm_source=openai))

input.query: Mário Leite da Silva Ironsea Capital Dubai Isabel dos Santos $58 million payment background business partner role
input.context: Due diligence investigation of Isabel dos Santos

output.search_result:
Mário Leite da Silva is a prominent figure in the business network of Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of former Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos. He has held significant managerial roles in several of her companies over the past 15 years. ([expresso.pt](https://expresso.pt/investigacao/luanda-leaks/2021-02-12-Luanda-Leaks.-Principal-gestor-de-Isabel-dos-Santos-fala-pela-primeira-vez-No-final-a-Sonangol-ficou-a-ganhar?utm_source=openai))

In 2016, Leite da Silva established Ironsea Consulting in Dubai, which was later renamed Matter Business Solutions in 2017. This company was contracted by Sonangol, Angola's state oil company, to coordinate the work of various international consultants involved in the company's restructuring project. ([expresso.pt](https://expresso.pt/investigacao/luanda-leaks/2021-02-12-Luanda-Leaks.-Principal-gestor-de-Isabel-dos-Santos-fala-pela-primeira-vez-No-final-a-Sonangol-ficou-a-ganhar?utm_source=openai))

Between 2017 and 2018, Sonangol transferred over $130 million to Matter Business Solutions for consultancy services. Notably, on November 16, 2017, just one day after Isabel dos Santos was dismissed from her position at Sonangol, the company transferred nearly $58 million to Matter Business Solutions. ([vozdeangola.com](https://www.vozdeangola.com/sociedade/item/5077-sonangol-para-onde-foram-os-131-milhoes-desviados-para-o-dubai?utm_source=openai))

Leite da Silva has stated that his compensation for the work performed through Matter was paid via a subcontract with Fidequity, a company owned by Isabel dos Santos and based in Lisbon. ([expresso.pt](https://expresso.pt/investigacao/luanda-leaks/2021-02-12-Luanda-Leaks.-Principal-gestor-de-Isabel-dos-Santos-fala-pela-primeira-vez-No-final-a-Sonangol-ficou-a-ganhar?utm_source=openai))

These financial transactions have been scrutinized by authorities in Angola and Portugal, with investigations into potential financial misconduct and misappropriation of funds. ([dw.com](https://www.dw.com/pt-002/sonangol-isabel-dos-santos-%C3%A9-acusada-de-12-crimes/a-67985328?utm_source=openai))

Leite da Silva's close association with Isabel dos Santos and his role in managing substantial financial flows have placed him at the center of these investigations.

- **KPMG:** KPMG's involvement was noted in the context of providing services to entities associated with dos Santos, though specific details were less prominently reported compared to PwC and BCG. ([transparencia.pt](https://transparencia.pt/luanda-leaks-fluxos-financeiros/?utm_source=openai))

([news24.com](https://www.news24.com/angola-one-last-gift-from-father-to-daughter-20170903-2?utm_source=openai))

In July 2018, the Angolan government issued a presidential decree to modify the consortium, removing companies associated with Isabel dos Santos, including CGGC & Niara Holding Limitada and Boreal Investment Ltd., citing the need to maintain the contract's financial balance. ([angola24horas.com](https://www.angola24horas.com/economia/item/10979-empresa-associada-a-isabel-dos-santos-retirada-na-obra-de-us-4-5-mil-milhoes-em-angola?utm_source=openai))

José Filomeno dos Santos, known as "Zenu," was sentenced to five years in prison in August 2020 for fraud and influence peddling during his tenure as head of Angola's sovereign wealth fund from 2013 to 2018. He was accused of embezzling $500 million from the fund and transferring it to a Swiss bank account. ([aljazeera.com](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/8/14/angola-sentences-ex-presidents-son-to-five-year-jail-for-fraud?utm_source=openai))

In contrast, Isabel dos Santos, daughter of former President José Eduardo dos Santos, has faced multiple legal challenges. In December 2022, Angola's Supreme Court ordered the seizure of assets worth approximately $1 billion held by her, citing evidence of alleged embezzlement and money laundering. ([aljazeera.com](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/12/28/angolan-court-orders-seizure-of-dos-santoss-assets-lusa-news-agency?utm_source=openai)) In June 2023, she was convicted of embezzling €52.6 million from Sonangol, Angola's state oil company. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonangol_Group?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in November 2024, the UK government imposed a travel ban and asset freeze on her under its global anti-corruption sanctions regime, accusing her of misappropriating over £50 million while leading Sonangol and over £300 million during her tenure at telecoms company Unitel. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/britain-imposes-asset-freeze-travel-ban-angolas-isabel-dos-santos-2024-11-21/?utm_source=openai))

Both individuals have been implicated in significant financial misconduct during their respective tenures in state-owned enterprises. While Zenu's conviction was finalized in 2020, Isabel dos Santos continues to face legal proceedings and international sanctions as of December 2025.

In Portugal, where Isabel dos Santos held significant investments, legal proceedings were initiated to seize assets connected to her and her family's business interests. The Portuguese government sought to enforce Angolan court orders and international sanctions by freezing assets believed to be linked to illicit activities. These actions were part of broader efforts to recover assets allegedly misappropriated from Angola.

**Current Status**

As of December 2025, the legal proceedings in both Angola and Portugal are ongoing. The frozen assets remain under investigation, and the final distribution of Sindika Dokolo's estate has yet to be fully resolved. The complex nature of international asset recovery and the legal challenges faced by Isabel dos Santos have contributed to the prolonged duration of these proceedings.

input.query: José Filomeno dos Santos Zenu prison release 2025 parole sentence completion Angola current status
input.context: Due diligence investigation of Isabel dos Santos

output.search_result:
José Filomeno dos Santos, known as "Zenu," the son of former Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos, was convicted in August 2019 for embezzling $500 million during his tenure as chairman of the Angolan Sovereign Fund. In December 2024, President João Lourenço granted a presidential pardon to 51 individuals, including Zenu, effective January 1, 2025, citing their good behavior and lack of social danger. ([opais.ao](https://www.opais.ao/politica/indulto-presidencial-concede-liberdade-a-zenu-dos-santos-e-outros-50-cidadaos/?utm_source=openai))

Initially, Zenu declined the pardon, stating that accepting it would imply guilt for a crime he claimed not to have committed. ([novojornal.co.ao](https://novojornal.co.ao/sociedade/detalhe/supremo-confirma-que-filho-de-jes-ainda-nao-levantou-passaporte-apesar-do-indulto-do-pr-63551.html?utm_source=openai)) However, in March 2025, he accepted the pardon and retrieved his passports from the Supreme Court, which had been previously confiscated. ([novojornal.co.ao](https://novojornal.co.ao/sociedade/detalhe/zenu-dos-santos-aceita-indulto-de-jlo-apos-recusa-em-janeiro-e-levanta-passaporte-no-tribunal-supremo-64698.html?utm_source=openai))

In April 2024, Angola's Constitutional Court annulled all Supreme Court rulings against Zenu, declaring the entire legal process unconstitutional and null. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Filomeno_dos_Santos?utm_source=openai)) Consequently, Zenu's conviction was overturned, and he was released from prison.

As of December 2025, there are no public reports indicating any further legal actions or restrictions against José Filomeno dos Santos.

input.query: UK sanctions Isabel dos Santos frozen assets list implementation 2024 2025 enforcement Treasury designation
input.context: Due diligence investigation of Isabel dos Santos

output.search_result:
On November 21, 2024, the UK government imposed a travel ban and asset freeze on Isabel dos Santos under its Global Anti-Corruption Sanctions Regulations 2021. Dos Santos, daughter of Angola's former president, is accused of misappropriating over £50 million while leading Sonangol and over £300 million during her tenure at Unitel. She denies the allegations, claiming they are part of a political vendetta. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/britain-imposes-asset-freeze-travel-ban-angolas-isabel-dos-santos-2024-11-21/?utm_source=openai))

The Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation (OFSI) has included Isabel dos Santos in the UK Sanctions List, subjecting her to an asset freeze and travel ban. This designation is part of the UK's broader efforts to combat corruption and enforce financial sanctions. ([assets.publishing.service.gov.uk](https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/673f084db3f0df6d2ebaf003/Notice_Global_Anti_Corruption_211124.pdf?utm_source=openai))

As of October 2025, the UK government announced that from January 28, 2026, the UK Sanctions List will become the single authoritative source for all UK sanctions designations, consolidating previous lists to simplify compliance. ([steptoe.com](https://www.steptoe.com/en/news-publications/international-compliance-blog/weekly-sanctions-update-october-20-2025.html?utm_source=openai))

The UK has also sanctioned other individuals under the same anti-corruption initiative, including Paula Oliveira and Sarju Raikundalia, who are associated with Isabel dos Santos. ([gov.uk](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-cracks-down-on-dirty-money-with-fresh-sanctions?utm_source=openai))

For the most current information on UK sanctions and designated individuals, refer to the UK Sanctions List published by the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office. ([gov.uk](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/uk-sanctions?utm_source=openai))

input.query: Mário Leite da Silva arrest warrant Interpol cooperation agreement witness testimony Angola Portugal status
input.context: Due diligence investigation of Isabel dos Santos

output.search_result:
Mário Leite da Silva, a Portuguese businessman and associate of Isabel dos Santos, has been implicated in multiple investigations concerning alleged financial misconduct. In December 2019, the Luanda Provincial Court ordered the preemptive freezing of bank accounts belonging to dos Santos, her husband Sindika Dokolo, and Leite da Silva, suspecting that these assets originated from unlawfully obtained state funds. ([fln.dk](https://fln.dk/media/ezfjw2zj/ango100.pdf?utm_source=openai))

In January 2020, Angolan authorities issued a rogatory letter to Portugal, requesting the preventive seizure of assets linked to dos Santos and her associates, including Leite da Silva, totaling up to €1.15 billion. ([cedesa.pt](https://www.cedesa.pt/tag/state/?utm_source=openai))

Leite da Silva has been questioned by Dutch authorities in connection with investigations into Esperaza Holding BV, a company associated with dos Santos. Dutch experts reconstructed financial transactions involving large sums transferred from Esperaza to Exem Energy, with Leite da Silva providing testimony during this process. ([negociosdeangola.com](https://www.negociosdeangola.com/en/investigation-isabel-dos-santos-and-frontman-convicted-of-mismanagement/?utm_source=openai))

As of December 2025, there is no public information indicating that an Interpol arrest warrant has been issued for Mário Leite da Silva. While Angolan authorities have sought international cooperation, including potential arrest warrants for dos Santos, specific details regarding Leite da Silva's status remain unclear. ([sabcnews.com](https://www.sabcnews.com/sabcnews/angola-may-seek-international-arrest-warrant-for-isabel-dos-santos-reports/?utm_source=openai))

The investigations into Leite da Silva's activities are ongoing, with authorities in Angola, Portugal, and the Netherlands collaborating to address the alleged financial irregularities.

output.search_result: In April 2024, Angola's Constitutional Court declared the conviction of José Filomeno dos Santos, son of former President José Eduardo dos Santos, unconstitutional. The court cited violations of the principles of legality, adversarial proceedings, fair trial, and the right to defense. Specifically, the Supreme Court had disregarded a letter from José Eduardo dos Santos authorizing Valter Filipe da Silva, former governor of the National Bank of Angola, to transfer funds. The Constitutional Court emphasized that this letter was essential for uncovering the material truth and safeguarding constitutional guarantees. Consequently, the court annulled the previous ruling and instructed that the case be reassessed to address the identified constitutional violations. ([verangola.net](https://www.verangola.net/va/en/042024/Defense/39507/Court-considers-conviction-of-%E2%80%9CZenu%E2%80%9D-dos-Santos-and-Valter-Filipe-unconstitutional.htm?utm_source=openai))

In 2006, Angola's state oil company, Sonangol, sold a 40% stake in Esperaza Holding BV to Exem Energy BV, a company owned by Isabel dos Santos's husband, Sindika Dokolo. This transaction, valued at $99 million, was structured with an initial payment of $15 million, with the remainder due by December 2017. ([icij.org](https://www.icij.org/investigations/luanda-leaks/director-mismanagement-enabled-isabel-dos-santos-to-illegally-divert-millions-dutch-court-finds/?utm_source=openai))

In 2020, a Dutch court froze Exem Energy's assets and removed Mario Silva, a key associate of dos Santos, from Esperaza's board, pending an investigation into the legality of the acquisition. ([icij.org](https://www.icij.org/investigations/luanda-leaks/dutch-court-orders-key-business-associate-of-isabel-dos-santos-removed-pending-investigation/?utm_source=openai))

Subsequently, in 2021, the Enterprise Chamber of the Amsterdam Court of Appeal ruled that the 2006 sale was "contaminated by illegality," allowing Exem's owners to influence Sonangol's control and gain extraordinary financial advantages to the detriment of the Angolan state. The court declared the transaction null and void, reinstating Sonangol as the sole owner of Esperaza Holding BV. ([icij.org](https://www.icij.org/investigations/luanda-leaks/dutch-court-sides-with-report-calling-dos-santos-linked-energy-deal-an-act-of-corruption/?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, a report by a court-appointed director of Esperaza Holding BV concluded that the 2006 sale was an "act of corruption" and should be voided. ([icij.org](https://www.icij.org/investigations/luanda-leaks/dutch-court-sides-with-report-calling-dos-santos-linked-energy-deal-an-act-of-corruption/?utm_source=openai))

In 2023, a Dutch court found that mismanagement by directors and forged documents enabled Isabel dos Santos to illegally divert €52.6 million from Sonangol to a business she controlled. ([icij.org](https://www.icij.org/investigations/luanda-leaks/director-mismanagement-enabled-isabel-dos-santos-to-illegally-divert-millions-dutch-court-finds/?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, a Portuguese court ordered the return of €83 million seized from Esperaza's bank accounts to Sonangol, stating that the funds were not the product of any crime. ([verangola.net](https://www.verangola.net/va/en/052022/Defense/30988/Portuguese-court-orders-the-return-to-Sonangol-of-83-million-euros-seized-from-the-company-linked-to-Isabel-dos-Santos.htm?utm_source=openai))

input.query: Isabel dos Santos constitutional appeal Angola trial 2024 2025 procedural violations challenge Sérgio Raimundo legal strategy
input.context: Due diligence investigation of Isabel dos Santos

output.search_result:
Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of former Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos, has been embroiled in legal proceedings concerning alleged financial misconduct during her tenure at Sonangol, Angola's state oil company. In May 2025, the Angolan Supreme Court initiated the "instrução contraditória" phase of her trial, a procedural step in Angolan criminal law aimed at assessing the viability of the prosecution's case. This phase was scheduled to commence on May 22, 2025. ([verangola.net](https://www.verangola.net/va/pt/052025/Defesa/44406/Processo-de-Isabel-dos-Santos-com-instru%C3%A7%C3%A3o-contradit%C3%B3ria-marcada-para-22-de-Maio-em-Luanda.htm?utm_source=openai))

Sérgio Raimundo, Isabel dos Santos' defense attorney, has been actively challenging the prosecution's case. He has argued that the "instrução contraditória" has been instrumental in clarifying aspects of the accusations, suggesting that some charges may be dismissed as a result. Raimundo emphasized the importance of this phase, stating that it allows for a thorough examination of the facts presented in the indictment. ([eco.sapo.pt](https://eco.sapo.pt/2025/06/27/advogado-de-isabel-dos-santos-diz-que-instrucao-contraditoria-pode-fazer-cair-algumas-acusacoes/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to procedural challenges, Isabel dos Santos has faced international legal actions. In September 2024, the UK Court of Appeal upheld an asset-freezing order against her, related to a lawsuit filed by Angolan telecom operator Unitel. The court's decision was based on allegations that she misappropriated funds during her directorship at Unitel. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/angolas-isabel-dos-santos-loses-appeal-against-freezing-order-over-assets-2024-09-30/?utm_source=openai))

Furthermore, in November 2024, the UK government imposed sanctions on Isabel dos Santos, including a travel ban and asset freeze, under its global anti-corruption regime. These sanctions were imposed due to allegations of misappropriation of funds during her tenure at Sonangol and Unitel. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/britain-imposes-asset-freeze-travel-ban-angolas-isabel-dos-santos-2024-11-21/?utm_source=openai))

Isabel dos Santos has consistently denied all allegations, asserting that the legal actions against her are politically motivated. She maintains that all contracts and transactions were legal and aimed at modernizing Angola's state-owned enterprises.

In November 2024, the United Kingdom imposed sanctions on Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of former Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos, citing her involvement in significant corruption. The UK government stated that she "exploited her position to amass wealth through corrupt practices." 

Paula Oliveira, a Portuguese national, has been identified as a close associate of Isabel dos Santos. Oliveira has held various positions within dos Santos's business empire, including roles in companies such as Unitel, Angola's largest mobile telecommunications company, and Banco BIC, a prominent Angolan bank. Her involvement in these entities has been scrutinized due to their connections to dos Santos's alleged corrupt activities.

In 2019, the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) reported that Paula Oliveira was among the individuals who facilitated the transfer of significant sums of money from Angola to offshore accounts, raising concerns about money laundering and financial misconduct. 

The UK's sanctions against Isabel dos Santos have extended to her close associates, including Paula Oliveira, due to their roles in facilitating and benefiting from the alleged corrupt activities. These sanctions aim to hold individuals accountable for actions that undermine the integrity of financial systems and promote corruption.
